text:
I had an amazing stroke of luck finding this game. It was early September 2012, when I had spent the summer refurbishing an SNES from the ground up (Bought the console by itself, had to find a Power Adapter, AV cord, controllers and games.) I took a trip to the local Value Village...and someone who had NO DAMN CLUE what they had put this game out for 4 bucks. 

Oh yeah, it was complete in the box as well. Right down to the original Reciept that the original owner got when he bought it from the Seven Oaks mall in Abbotsford, BC on September 1st, 1995.

This is my favorite song in the game.

text:
Everyone seems to have a lot to say about Wiz and I don’t know if I like the way he’s using this song either. But, to keep things in perspective this song is not a wholly original piece. It’s more of a sped up remix of a piece by Ravel titled “pavane pour une infante defunte”, or in English “Death of an Infant”.

I wonder if fans of classical music are mad at Chrono Triggers composer for repurposing a methodically somber piece or if they’re glad it’s getting exposure even if no one seems to know it.

author: repmem 909178

text:
@POLYHAX™  This type of music isn't more "intellectually challenging" than any other. The implication that people who prefer Justin Bieber because his music is less "intellectually challenging" are ,therefore, not only less intelligent and use drugs/have sex is totally unfounded and ridiculous. Can you actually give reasons as to why this is more "challenging" when compared to a typical JB song? The fact that you find this more stimulating only says that YOU aren't willing to put any thought into interpreting JB's music.

Note: I say this all as someone who doesn't even like Justin Bieber. I just think you need to get off your high horse and see that music that you don't like isn't for people who aren't as intelligent as you (think you) are
author: Brndn-97

text: +Brandon Thomas Your misuse of 'Ridiculous and unfounded' makes you sound like a complete and utter twit. Furthermore, your argument is filled with blatant attempts to put words in my mouth. It's an opinion, otherwise I wouldn't have called it a 'Subjective judgement'. I did explicitly state 'Some people'. It's a given that Bach's 'Goldberg Variations' are more intellectually challenging than Justin Bieber's music, because they had artistic effort and intelligence put into them. Perhaps you need to actually read people's comments thoroughly before you start jumping to conclusions.
author: repmem 909178

text: You need to distinguish between “a lot of thought was put into this song“ and “it takes a lot of thought to appreciate this song”. I don’t think the fact that you clicked through to this video makes you any more intelligent than any JB fan—in fact, just about any old twat could do that. It just means you probably have a taste for enigmatic-sounding Japanese music or something like that.
author: Ron Wolf

text: @Ron Wolf What are you going on about? I  was speaking generally about the artistic inspiration or design that goes into a piece of music, not my  tastes specifically. Of course thought needs to be put into a song for it to be appreciated because then newer developments in the study of music can come about. Anyone can argue a piece of music is more intellectually challenging than another and anyone can argue against that person's conviction. It doesn't make you unintelligent if you like a piece of music that had little thought put into it or mean you have to agree with those who deem it shallow. I don't understand your point.
author: repmem 909178

text: Claiming that certain music is more 'intellectualy challenging' than others is simply not true. People need to be exposed to different types of music in order to learn to appreciate it. It has nothing to do with intelligience or imagination. That statement is pure snobbery.
author: Zephyr49

text: @Zephyr49 Yes you can claim a piece is more 'intellectually challenging' than other. It's called  an opinion.  What you are stating is an opinion. Having an open-minded view about a subject doesn't make your view more superior than someone who claims a piece is more 'Intellectually challenging than another." They are entitled to their view of what they deem intellectual. What's intellectual is subjective, but people are still entitled to have a belief of what that may or may not include.
author: repmem 909178

text: Stating that the earth is flat is just an opinion, but that doesn't mean its factually correct. There exists no such thing as 'intellecutaly challenging music', ask a scientist. Maybe you are referring to the fact that some musical genres are more complex than other genres.  This is true, but you don't need more intelligience to appreciate it. Classical music, jazz & math rock are one of the most complex musical genres, but expose a kid to this at a young age and he'll learn to appreciate it just as much as exposing him to pop music.
author: Zephyr49

text:
@Zephyr49 Exactly, an "Opinion cannot be factually correct", and so the view that a piece of music is more "Intellectually challenging" than another is just an opinion. You are making the assumption that all opinions have to take all other viewpoints into account to be considered legitimate.

And therefore, it would be in your view illegitimate for someone to deem a piece as more 'Intellectually challenging" than another because other people think differently. People may hold a view of what they deem an intellectually challenging piece but it doesn't mean they have to forfeit their view just because you (personally) believe that they should appreciate all music as being intellectually challenging.

text:
serial disliker
A person who clicks the little red thumbs-down icon on EVERY YouTube video they watch (even videos which have no perceivable reason to be "disliked" at all), purely for the sake of doing so. It's believed that most serial dislikers suffer from a form of OCD currently unknown to science. No one knows who these people are, particularly since YouTube doesn't keep any record of who dislikes what, so research cannot be undertaken.

These people don't necessarily hate the video, but will still click "dislike" just for fun, especially if said video has no dislikes at all yet. They then delight in watching the comment section fall to ruin as a direct result of their interference, with highly intellectual and imaginative responses such as "1 person is gay", or "1 person should jump off a cliff", or "Justin Bieber made a new account to dislike this video" appearing in it.

Furthermore, the less "likes" a video has, the more devastating are the actions of the serial disliker, due to YouTube's like/dislike bar being based on the proportion between likes and dislikes, rather than on actual numbers. 1 dislike shows up as a much bigger chunk of red on the bar for a video with only 3 likes, than for one with 150. In the former case, it's much more noticeable and the commenters' outrage is slightly more justified, though in the latter case, the reactionary comments take on forms not unlike "the dislike bar is the size of Justin Bieber's penis", which is inexcusable.

-Urban Dictionary

text: Reason A: they think he isn't very creative by sampling. Reason B: they think he is stealing wholesale from MItsuda/Square-Enix and are complicit in a crime by not getting angry., Reason C: they feel threatened by more mainstream audience hearing it and then calling this an inferior cover. Reason D; they just strongly dislike any association with a beloved piece of VGM and rap/hip hop. Honestly, everyone should stop worrying and be glad a mainstream artist has validated this by sampling it on one of their albums. Another way to look at it, is that it gives people potential exposure to this soundtrack that would not have been aware of it before, if they think "wow that is a killer sample" and find the source. I've found quite a few gems myself this way.

author: Billy Garcia

text: @HombreHonest Yes. It is a great RPG. It has the depth that hardcore players crave, while still being very accessible to the casual RPG gamer. For it's time, it was ground breaking because of the re-playability and the many different endings that you can get (for the SNES, more than 2 or 3 endings was unheard of, let alone the 13 offered by Chrono Trigger). That story is classic good vs. evil with awesome twists, and characters you generally care about. It was and is the total RPG package.

This song yearns me to find that place, a forest left to grow, far away from man to interfere and destroy that beautiful place...I think I went too into it.
